abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Grenada emergency recovery
            project were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial and the Bank and borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: The Bank
            is well positioned to respond to similar emergencies in the
            future. The Bank can play an active role to assist countries
            in meeting established and evolving regulatory standards.
            There can be significant advantages to implementing
            multi-country programs through a regional entity with
            sufficient capacity. Regional procurement can bring
            important cost-benefits. The Emergency Recovery Project in
            Grenada was successful in great part thanks to the close and
            regular supervision of the Bank team. This was made possible
            by grouping supervision of five similar projects in the
            region, thereby creating significant economies of scale.
            With pooled supervision funds, the team was able to visit
            all participating islands on a single mission while paying
            transportation costs only once. Had this not been the case,
            the Bank team would not have had the funds required to be
            closely involved in project implementation - to the
            detriment of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Grenada - Emergency Recovery Project :
            proposed amendment to the loan and credit agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed amendment to the Loan
            Agreement between Grenada and the Bank and the Association
            for the Emergency Recovery Project (Loan 7100-GRD and Credit
            361 1-GRD) authorizes the utilization of undisbursed Loan
            and Credit amounts to finance critical imports. The
            component will finance the purchase o f low sulfur diesel
            fuel for electricity generation and transport to support the
            Government's reconstruction efforts in response to the
            passage of Hurricane Ivan.

repnme.cdata!:
Organization of Eastern Caribbean States
            (OECS) - Five Emergency Recovery Projects (Dominica,
            Grenada, St. Christopher and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent
            and the Grenadines)

abstracts.cdata!:
This report combines five emergency
            recovery programs for five member states of the Organization
            of Eastern Caribbean States--Dominica, Grenada, St. Kitts
            and Nevis, St. Lucia, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines.
            The development objectives of these five Bank operations
            are: 1) to help safeguard and maintain the productive
            capacity of the countries' tourism sectors, notably by
            securing the industry's emergency needs in the
            aftermath of the September 11 events; 2) to enhance security
            at key airport and seaport facilities in line with
            international standards, with the aim of preventing further
            acts of terrorism and safeguarding the sub-region's
            image as a safe tourist destination; and 3) to strengthen
            the countries' institutional capacity to develop and
            implement security plans, procedures, and measures as
            mandated by the international civil aviation and marine
            transport regulatory agencies. There are two main project
            components. The first finances one critical import, low
            sulfur diesel fuel for electricity generation, which is
            critical to the maintenance of economic activity in the
            tourism industry by ensuring that the energy-intensive
            tourism facilities are kept operational during the recovery
            period. The second component finances the physical and
            technical resources needed for national port and aviation
            authorities, as well as individual airports and seaports, to
            upgrade security arrangements at key facilities and meet
            international regulations.
